declarations.comments: Construct a widget with just props
declarations.title: mkLeafWidget

declarations.comments: Construct a widget, by wrapping an existing widget in a view event
declarations.title: mkNodeWidget

declarations.comments: A Nice way to bring into scope all needed functionality which we need to write widgets
declarations.title: IsWidget

declarations.comments: A way to lift widgets into higher monads
declarations.title: LiftWidget

declarations.comments: Wrap a single widget with a node that can have eventHandlers attached
declarations.title: el

declarations.comments: Promote a leaf node to a widget
declarations.title: elLeaf

declarations.comments: Wrap some widgets with a node that can have eventHandlers attached
declarations.title: el'

declarations.comments:
Discharge a widget.
1. Runs the Effect action
2. Forks the Aff action
3. Extracts and returns the view
declarations.title: discharge

declarations.comments:
Discharge only the top level blocking effect of a widget (if any) to get access to the view
Returns the view, and the remaining widget
declarations.title: dischargePartialEffect

declarations.comments:
A View backend that can build nodes
e, f, p, v, are all raw types, highly specific to the backend
e  == type of element (e.g. 'div')
f  == props container (for example, an array)
p  == a single prop
v  == the monoidal view
declarations.title: ElementBuilder

declarations.comments:
A "Freeish" implementation of element builder
That fixes the type of view
declarations.title: Element

declarations.comments:
Poor man's FRP implementation for Concur.
I am experimenting with the smallest possible amount of FRP which can still be useful.
A Widget can be considered to be a one-shot Event. (There is no stream of events in Concur).
Signals then are never-ending widget loops that allow access to their last return value.
This last produced value allows composition with other widgets even for never-ending widgets.
declarations.title: SignalT

declarations.comments: A Signal specific to Widgets
declarations.title: Signal

declarations.comments: Construct a signal from an initial value, and a step widget
declarations.title: step

declarations.comments: Display a widget which returns a continuation
declarations.title: display

declarations.comments:
Fires a widget once then stop. This will reflow when a parent signal reflows
Starts as Nothing. Then switches to `Just returnVal` after the Widget is done
declarations.title: fireOnce

declarations.comments: Similar to `fireOnce`, but discards the return value
declarations.title: fireOnce_

declarations.comments: Wait until we get a `Just` value from a signal
declarations.title: justWait

declarations.comments: Run an effectful computation, and do something with the result
declarations.title: justEffect

declarations.comments: A constant signal
declarations.title: always

declarations.comments: Update signal to a new value
declarations.title: update

declarations.comments: Construct a signal by polling a signal with a nested widget for values
declarations.title: poll

declarations.comments:
Create a signal which repeatedly invokes a widget for values.
E.g. `signal False checkbox` will return a signal which reflects the current value of the checkbox.
declarations.title: hold

declarations.comments: Create a signal which repeatedly invokes a widget function for values, looping in the prev value.
declarations.title: loopW

declarations.comments: Loop a signal so that the return value is passed to the beginning again.
declarations.title: loopS

declarations.comments:
Loop a signal so that the return value is passed to the beginning again.
Folding signals. Similar to how signals used to work in Elm.
This can be used to implement simple stateful Signals.
e.g. `counter = fold (\n _ -> n+1) 0 clicks`
declarations.title: foldp

declarations.comments: Consume a closed signal to make a widget
declarations.title: dyn

declarations.comments: Run a signal *once* and return its value
declarations.title: oneShot

declarations.comments: A Gen is a widget that also generates things
declarations.title: Gen

declarations.comments: Sometimes it's useful to have Generators that generate Widgets
declarations.title: WidgetGen

declarations.comments: Yield a value
declarations.title: yield

declarations.comments: Run a Widget
declarations.title: runWidget

declarations.comments: Yield a value, and then continue
declarations.title: yieldAndThen

declarations.comments:
A map over yielded values (of type X)
The usual map is over the return value
declarations.title: mapYield

declarations.comments: Convert a generator into one that tags its output with successive unique integers
declarations.title: zipYield

declarations.comments:
Convert a monadic generator into one that tags its output with successive unique integers
Can also be specialised to :: WidgetGen v x a -> WidgetGen v (Tuple Int x) a
declarations.title: zipWidgetYield

declarations.comments:
Collapse a Generator into one widget. For containers with dynamic children.
Any new widgets generated are immediately inserted into the parent widget
Returns either (Left b) when Gen ends, or Right a, when one of the children end.
declarations.title: genOrr

declarations.comments:
Like `genOrr`, collapses a Generator into one widget.
However, any values returned by the children are tagged with an id (unique to this generator)
Any new widgets generated are immediately inserted into the parent widget
Returns either (Left b) when Gen ends, or (Tuple Int a), when one of the children end.
declarations.title: zipGenOrr

declarations.comments:
Array to Generator conversion
Sequentially generates all values in the list
declarations.title: listToGen

declarations.comments:
Generator to Array conversion. Runs until generator ends, then returns all generated values in an array.
Use it when you want to generate values, and then operate on them in one go
declarations.title: genToList

declarations.comments: A Nice way to bring into scope all needed functionality which we need to write widgets
declarations.title: IsWidget

declarations.comments: A way to lift widgets into higher monads
declarations.title: LiftWidget

declarations.comments: A very useful combinator for widgets with localised state
declarations.title: loopState

declarations.comments: Repeat a computation until the value satisfies a predicate
declarations.title: retryUntil

declarations.comments: Repeat a computation until the value satisfies a predicate, looping in the previous value
declarations.title: retryUntilLoop

declarations.comments: The Elm Architecture
declarations.title: tea

declarations.comments: Separate the effect of the widget from its result
declarations.title: remoteWidget

declarations.comments:
A common pattern - running a long running action and keeping the GUI responsive
Because the action can't be restarted on every gui event, we must *fork* it off in the beginning
declarations.title: forkAction

declarations.comments:
Another common variant on the `forkAction` pattern.
  The action `m (s->s)` may take a while (should not be restarted) and returns a state modification function
  The gui `s -> m s` takes in the current state, and modifies it on events
Note that `forkActionState axn` has the shape `(s -> m s) -> (s -> m s)`. So it can be "stacked" to fork multiple actions.
e.g. `forkActionState axn1 $ forkActionState axn2 $ forkActionState axn3 $ render initialState`.
declarations.title: forkActionState

declarations.comments: A wire can send values up into a local environment
declarations.title: Wire

declarations.comments: Map a Lens over a Wire
declarations.title: mapWire

declarations.comments: Setup a local environment with a wire
declarations.title: local

declarations.comments: Internal. Do not use. Use unsafeMkProp, or unsafeMkPropHandler instead.
declarations.title: mkProp

declarations.comments: Use `handleProp` to handle an event manually
declarations.title: handleProp

declarations.comments:
Use this to filter the output of an event handler prop.
For example, to only handle the enter key - `filterProp isEnterEvent onKeyDown`
declarations.title: filterProp

declarations.comments:
Run multiple widgets in parallel until *all* finish, and collect their outputs
Contrast with `orr`
declarations.title: andd

modules.comments:
AJ: This is the same as `Control.Comonad.Cofree` from the `purescript-free` package.
However, we need to override the applicative and monad instance, and "probably" due to a Purescript bug it's not working.
The _cofree comonad_ for a `Functor`.
This version also adds `lazyCofree`, `lazyHead`, `lazyTail`, and `mfix`

declarations.comments:
The `Cofree` `Comonad` for a functor.

A value of type `Cofree f a` consists of an `f`-branching
tree, annotated with labels of type `a`.

The `Comonad` instance supports _redecoration_, recomputing
labels from the local context.
declarations.title: Cofree

declarations.comments: Recursively unfolds a `Cofree` structure given a seed.
declarations.title: buildCofree

declarations.comments:
Lazily creates a value of type `Cofree f a` from a label and a
functor-full of "subtrees".
declarations.title: lazyCofree

declarations.comments:
Lazily creates a value of type `Cofree f a` from a label and a
functor-full of "subtrees".
declarations.title: deferCofree

declarations.comments:
Explore a value in the cofree comonad by using an expression in a
corresponding free monad.

The free monad should be built from a functor which pairs with the
functor underlying the cofree comonad.
declarations.title: explore

declarations.comments: Returns the label for a tree.
declarations.title: head

declarations.comments: Like `head`, but returns a lazy value
declarations.title: lazyHead

declarations.comments:
Create a value of type `Cofree f a` from a label and a
functor-full of "subtrees".
declarations.title: mkCofree

declarations.comments: Returns the "subtrees" of a tree.
declarations.title: tail

declarations.comments: Like `tail`, but returns a lazy value
declarations.title: lazyTail

declarations.comments:
This signature is deprecated and will be replaced by `buildCofree` in a
future release.
declarations.title: unfoldCofree

modules.name: Control.Cofree

declarations.comments:
Type class for monads that support fixpoints.

`mfix f` runs `f` once with the eventual result of `f` as input. Make sure
not to apply the supplied function until the computation returned; else
a dynamic error will be thrown.
declarations.title: MonadFix

declarations.comments:
Avoiding monad-control for as long as possible
(convert functions on widgets to functions on transformer stacks
wrapping widgets).
declarations.title: ShiftMap
